name: allium-sativum
definition: An onionlike plant having a bulb that breaks up into separable cloves with a strong distinctive odor and flavor.
description:
Garlic is a an herbaceous, annual, bulbous plant grown for its pungent, edible bulb of the same name.

Its close relatives include the onion, shallot, leek, chive, and Chinese onion.

There are more than 300 varieties of garlic today that are cultivated usually in temperate and cold climates.

Depending on the variety, the long leaves typically arise from a short hard stem above the bulb or emerge from a softer pseudostem made up of overlapping leaf sheaths.

The garlic plant can possess 6 to 12 flat, blade-like leaves which can stretch up to 50 centimeters long.

The bulb is covered with membranous skin and encloses up to 20 edible bulblets called cloves.

The plant can reach 60 centimeters in height and is an annual, surviving only one growing season.

Garlic produces hermaphrodite flowers that are pollinated by bees, butterflies, moths, and other insects.

The bulbs have a powerful onion like aroma and pungent taste and are not usually eaten raw.

In ancient and medieval times, garlic was prized for its medicinal properties and was carried as a charm against vampires and other evils.

The plant is used in traditional and folk medicine in many places, and there is some evidence that it may help prevent heart disease.

People cultivate garlic mainly as a source of food.

Other than that, garlic has application in medical and pharmaceutical industry, gardening (chemicals from the garlic repel pests) and in the industry of adhesives and food preservatives.

Garlic contains about 0.1 percent essential oil.

Garlic is a hardy perennial which can be grown in a variety of soil types.

The plants perform best when planted in a light, well draining, organic loam.

The plant grows well in cool weather but will tolerate a range from 9 to 28°C.

If garlic is planted at the proper time and depth, it can be grown as far north as Alaska.

Garlic should be planted in an area that receives full sun for most of the day.

It requires a period of cold followed by a period of light and heat in order to develop properly.

China produces some 80% of the world's supply of garlic.

Garlic is native to Central Asia and northeastern Iran, and has long been a common seasoning worldwide, with a history of several thousand years of human consumption and use.

It was known to ancient Egyptians, and has been used both as a food flavoring and as a traditional medicine.

In Ancient Rome, it was much used for food among the poor.

contextual.caption: Garlic is usually grown as an annual crop and is propagated by planting cloves or top bulbils, though seeds can be also be used.

featured.caption:
Like most flowering bulbs, garlic reproduces primarily through the bulbs.

However, some garlic varieties will also end up a flower stalk that can produce seeds.

facts.name: All parts of the plant are edible
facts.value: Even though all parts of the plant (except root) are edible, bulb is typically used in human diet.

facts.name: Garlic is used for centuries
facts.value: Garlic is used as food and medicine for centuries. Builders of pyramids in the ancient Egypt were living on a diet based on garlic, bread and water. Garlic was used in treatment of intestinal parasites, respiratory disorders, indigestion and lack of energy in the ancient Greece.

facts.name: Was used against evil spirits
facts.value: Garlic was used against evil spirits, demons and vampires in the Europe in the past.

facts.name: Can be consumed raw
facts.value: Garlic can be used raw, pickled or as an ingredient of various salty dishes, salads, sauces, and marinades.

facts.name: Greatest manufacturer in the world
facts.value: China is the greatest manufacturer of garlic in the world. It produces 10.5 million tons of garlic (77% of globally consumed garlic) each year.

facts.name: Greenish, white or pink flowers
facts.value: Garlic produces greenish, white or pink flowers arranged in spherical umbel (type of inflorescence). Flowers develop at the end of long scapes (flower stalks). Garlic produces hermaphrodite flowers (they contain both types of reproductive organs). Bees and other types of insects are responsible for the pollination.

facts.name: Can grow up to 1.2 meters
facts.value: Garlic can grow to the height of 4 feet.

facts.name: Beneficial for cardiovascular system
facts.value: Latest medical studies showed that garlic acts beneficially on the cardiovascular system of humans. It prevents accumulation of fats on the arterial walls and lowers blood cholesterol level. Compounds isolated from garlic possess antibacterial (kill bacteria) properties.

facts.name: Develops up to 10 leaves
facts.value: Garlic develops 4 to 10 smooth, green leaves. They are flat or V-shaped on the cross-section.

facts.name: Garlic has short, disk-shaped stem
facts.value: Garlic has short, disk-shaped stem that forms at the base of the plant.

facts.name: Was used on wedding ceremonies
facts.value: Bouquets made of garlic and other herbs (instead of floral bouquets) were part of wedding ceremonies in the ancient Greece.

facts.name: Ovoid bulb with up to 20 cloves
facts.value: Garlic produces ovoid bulb that consists of up to 20 cloves. Color of the bulb depends on the variety. Most common types of garlic have white or pinkish bulbs. Root is located on the basal part of the bulb.

facts.name: Cultivated as annual plant
facts.value: Garlic is cultivated as annual plant (plant that completes its life cycle in one year).

facts.name: Crushing of cloves release enzymes
facts.value: Crushing of garlic cloves induces release of enzymes which trigger creation of sulfur compounds that are responsible for the pungent and long lasting odor of garlic.

facts.name: Rich source of vitamin C and Bx
facts.value: Garlic is rich source of vitamin C and vitamins of the B group. It also contains dietary fibers and minerals such as manganese, phosphorus, calcium and zinc.
